key_points: Dave Halls, a first assistant director, admitted to not properly checking a gun before a fatal incident on the 'Rust' set.
Crew members from a previous film, 'One Way,' warned 'Rust' producers about Halls' disregard for safety.
'One Way' production saw unsafe situations involving vehicles and insufficient stunt coordination.
Jay Graves, set dresser on 'One Way,' described it as the least safe set he's ever worked on.
A production shutdown occurred on 'One Way' due to nearly colliding vehicles.
Molly Mayeux, line producer for 'One Way,' claimed all safety protocols were followed and denied being warned about Halls.
Halls was previously fired from 'Freedom's Path' in 2019 due to a gun-related incident.
Thomasville Pictures, involved in 'Rust' and 'One Way,' faced criticism for late payments and poor accommodations on another project, 'Bandit'.
Heather McReynolds expressed frustrations with Thomasville's management and social media posts during 'Bandit'.
J.M. Stelly defended Halls and 'One Way' producers, pointing out their good treatment and questioning how a live round appeared on 'Rust'.
